comment.author: 31324280@N02
comment._content: If I am not mistaken, the destroyer in the background looks to be an ex RN V&W class destroyer, with the pennant number D 31. In that case it might be HMAS Voyager (D 31). Serving in the RAN from Dec 1933 until Apr '36. Recommissioned in April '38 and lost during the war. It might help narrowing down the respective vessel's times together. Seen here on Flickr: www.flickr.com/photos/41311545@N05/3883849044/

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/31324280@N02] Hmm, it's quite difficult to say for sure but thank you for that information, we will put that in our database. :)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 31324280@N02
comment._content: OK, what I am fairly sure about is that the destroyer is a V&W class. I have been around a working model all my life! The pennant number ends in 31 - HMS Voyager ended up RN service as D 31, started RAN service as such and then D 131. See: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMAS_Voyager_%28D31%29 Model (HMS VIdette): [http://www.flickr.com/photos/31324280@N02/6186348790/in/set-72157624254936157] None of which tells you the name of the cruiser....

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/31324280@N02] Thanks for your help in any case. Love the little model! Thanks for sharing. :)

comment.author: 41311545@N05
comment._content:
From the unfamiliar aircraft carried and the Union Jack at the bow, we can say this is definitely not HMAS AUSTRALIA [II] or CANBERRA. Pretty sure it is HMS SUSSEX bringing the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester to Australia in 1934, actually to mark the Centenary of Victoria [and open the Shrine of Remembrance in Melbourne, and then the Anzac War Memorial in Sydney]. Visitng Sydney in November, 1934,  the visitors and ship received a huge small boat line-up welcome in Farm Cove, and I'm sure you have other Sam Hood photos of that event. Should give you an exact date of their arrival, too. . This photo is one of a number taken from Fort Denison. 

HMS SUSSEX remained in Australia on exchange while HMAS AUSTRALIA took the Royal couple back to Britain in early 1935. Gloucester came back to Australia as Governor General in 1939. Cheers, K.  .

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/41311545@N05] Ha! I think you have a winning ticket there. Slightly later photos from the SLNSW - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=9763 acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=9760 [off in search of newspaper reports ... ]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: It was Thursday 22 November 1934 - Read All About It! - SMH 23/11/1934 p.11- trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/page/1140554 - " ... The day was perfect for. the welcome. It was a sunny morning, with a thin veil of cloud tempering the warmth, and just enough wind to lift the bunting bravely, to give a sparkle to the blue water of the harbour, and to waft away the smoke lrom the guns firing. SCENE IN FARM COVE. Sydney's favoured approach being by the sea, this was a marine welcome. The. warships coming up the harbour were met by boats of all kinds. People were clustered on the prominent headlands. The city began to fill with people, and the general trend was towards Macquarle-street and the Botanic Gardens. At about, 10 o'clock the crowds became dense everywhere. many people taking up positions in the streets to await the procession. Farm Cove was a glorious picture. Verdant grass formed a foreground beyond which was the small while pavilion at the landing place rising above a forest of white staffs in a glitter of colour as the flag fluttered. White yachts were gathered in the bay, behind the two lines forming a lane through which the Royal barge was to travel, and close by were the naval vessels, in all their majesty and imposing might, with sailors landing in llnes on the decks and offlcers in cocked hats moving about. Yachts flecked the picture as they moved among the big grey ships. At the landing place, the rising ground, crowded with people among the trees built up a background. The guard of honour was waiting, distinguished personages were at the reception platform, bands played at intervals till half past 10. Then there was a lull. A sense of expectancy came over the scene, and the hubbub of the throng died to a dull murmur. ... ... "
